8fe73e72-53b5-44ef-b84a-2a59b1a74318.source:
# Data Processing with Ray Data
¬© 2025, Anyscale. All Rights Reserved

8f40d12a-35dc-4e63-b019-c85959ec8ab8.source:
üíª **Launch Locally**: You can run this notebook locally.

üöÄ **Launch on Cloud**: Think about running this notebook on a Ray Cluster (Click [here](http://console.anyscale.com/register) to easily start a Ray cluster on Anyscale)

0f7489a2-2faf-40ba-90fa-d3a02b90ba12.source:
Data preprocessing is a crucial step in any machine learning workflow, and Ray Data provides a scalable and flexible way to handle this process on large datasets. With Ray Data, you can efficiently load, transform, filter, and join datasets using a distributed framework that leverages the power of multiple CPUs or nodes. This makes it possible to preprocess data that would be too large to fit into memory on a single machine, enabling seamless scaling from your laptop to a cluster.

Ray Data supports a variety of preprocessing operations, such as filtering rows based on conditions, joining multiple datasets, and applying custom transformations like tokenization or label encoding. For example, you can load a large public dataset like IMDB reviews, filter for only positive reviews, join with metadata, and tokenize the text‚Äîall in a distributed and parallelized manner. This approach not only speeds up data preparation but also integrates smoothly with downstream machine learning tasks, making Ray Data a powerful tool for modern data pipelines.

9ed48264-2b2b-4894-9fed-11e742a0d154.source:
### Outline of the notebook This notebook shows a few examples on how to preprocess data with Ray Data.
  • Library Imports
  • Initialize Ray and Load a Large Public Dataset
  • Convert to Ray Dataset
  • Create a Second Dataset
  • Filtering Data
  • Joining Datasets
  • Tokenization and Preprocessing
  • Converting to Pandas DataFrame
  • Shutting Down Ray
  • Conclusion

8f68cb99-c515-46a6-a473-7141c7bbf791.source:
import ray
from datasets import load_dataset
import pandas as pd
# showcase ray data transformations
from ray.data.preprocessors import Tokenizer

eef969cf-97d7-4f6d-b407-26c1ef607d44.source:
### Initialize Ray and Load a Dataset
Load a public dataset from Hugging Face and explore the dataset with a few sample rows.

imdb = load_dataset("imdb", split="train")

2849aad6-d401-44e5-a841-0dd553b6473e.source:
{'text': ['I rented I AM CURIOUS-YELLOW from my video store because of all the controversy that surrounded it when it was first released in 1967. I also heard that at first it was seized by U.S. customs if it ever tried to enter this country, therefore being a fan of films considered "controversial" I really had to see this for myself.

The plot is centered around a young Swedish drama student named Lena who wants to learn everything she can about life. In particular she wants to focus her attentions to making some sort of documentary on what the average Swede thought about certain political issues such as the Vietnam War and race issues in the United States. In between asking politicians and ordinary denizens of Stockholm about their opinions on politics, she has sex with her drama teacher, classmates, and married men.

What kills me about I AM CURIOUS-YELLOW is that 40 years ago, this was considered pornographic. Really, the sex and nudity scenes are few and far between, even then it\'s not shot like some cheaply made porno. While my countrymen mind find it shocking, in reality sex and nudity are a major staple in Swedish cinema. Even Ingmar Bergman, arguably their answer to good old boy John Ford, had sex scenes in his films.

I do commend the filmmakers for the fact that any sex shown in the film is shown for artistic purposes rather than just to shock people and make money to be shown in pornographic theaters in America. I AM CURIOUS-YELLOW is a good film for anyone wanting to study the meat and potatoes (no pun intended) of Swedish cinema. But really, this film doesn\'t have much of a plot.', '"I Am Curious: Yellow" is a risible and pretentious steaming pile. It doesn\'t matter what one\'s political views are because this film can hardly be taken seriously on any level. As for the claim that frontal male nudity is an automatic NC-17, that isn\'t true. I\'ve seen R-rated films with male nudity. Granted, they only offer some fleeting views, but where are the R-rated films with gaping vulvas and flapping labia? Nowhere, because they don\'t exist. The same goes for those crappy cable shows: schlongs swinging in the breeze but not a clitoris in sight. And those pretentious indie movies like The Brown Bunny, in which we\'re treated to the site of Vincent Gallo\'s throbbing johnson, but not a trace of pink visible on Chloe Sevigny. Before crying (or implying) "double-standard" in matters of nudity, the mentally obtuse should take into account one unavoidably obvious anatomical difference between men and women: there are no genitals on display when actresses appears nude, and the same cannot be said for a man. In fact, you generally won\'t see female genitals in an American film in anything short of porn or explicit erotica. This alleged double-standard is less a double standard than an admittedly depressing ability to come to terms culturally with the insides of women\'s bodies.', "If only to avoid making this type of film in the future. This film is interesting as an experiment but tells no cogent story.

One might feel virtuous for sitting thru it because it touches on so many IMPORTANT issues but it does so without any discernable motive. The viewer comes away with no new perspectives (unless one comes up with one while one's mind wanders, as it will invariably do during this pointless film).

One might better spend one's time staring out a window at a tree growing.

"], 'label': [0, 0, 0]}

ef06c018-c62c-46e1-b183-f8983898807f.source:
## Convert to Ray Dataset
Add unique IDs to each row and create a Ray Dataset. Ray Dataset is distributed across the nodes and enables parallel computations.

2026a643-2ba5-4ce1-be53-565bfc821415.source:
### Create a Second Dataset
Here we create a second dataset (fake metadata) with some rows with common IDs as in ds_reviews data. In practice, you would have a real metadata or another dataset. This used to show join operation between two Ray datasets.

8c22dce6-1182-4062-acd5-02e64110738d.source:
# Create a second dataset: pretend we have metadata (source column) for every 100th row.
# This is just for demonstration purposes; in practice, you would have a real metadata source.
ds_meta = ray.data.from_items([
    {"id": i, "source": "imdb"} for i in range(0, len(imdb), 100)
])

00d8a1e4-a54e-4957-af8e-0ffb4af83791.source:
## Filter Ray Dataset
This show how to filter some rows in a Ray dataset. In this example, a filter expression is applied to keep only positive reviews.

* Filter can be an expression or a function. Expression API is faster than functional API.
* Concurrency parameter is used to launch multiple workers. If it not set (default), number of workers is determined by the available resources and the number of input blocks.

a2eda4be-3cf7-4da6-94b8-69f9ff6ee7c1.source:
# Filter: keep only positive reviews
# using expression API, faster than lambda
# concurrency=2 is used to parallelize the filtering operation
# Note: If you have a large dataset, consider using a larger concurrency value for better performance
# filtered = ds_reviews.filter(expr="label == 1", concurrency=2)

# functional API, slower than expression API
filtered = ds_reviews.filter(lambda row: row["label"] == 1)

+- Dataset(num_rows=25000, schema={id: int64, text: string, label: int64})

7ef76d1e-e13e-4671-b53a-96d757df4d7d.source:
## Join Two Ray Datasets
Here we show a join operation by joining the filtered reviews with the metadata dataset on 'id'. This is a simple inner join operation to demonstrate how to combine datasets.

Note: num_partitions=2 is used here for demonstration; adjust based on your dataset
size and performance needs. The join operation can be expensive, so consider the size of your datasets.

836acc09-8526-4e92-bdc4-aadbca82dd74.source:
# Join: inner join on 'id'
joined = filtered.join(ds_meta, on=("id",), join_type="inner", num_partitions=2)

This showcases a preprocessing method that tokenizes the text column using custom tokenization function. Such preprocessing methods are useful in preparing the data for training a model.

### Convert to Pandas DataFrame
Converting the processed Ray Dataset to a Pandas DataFrame for further analysis.

9c0ab43a-b01a-4a04-8802-0439a6bbded8.source:
# Get a tokenized Pandas DataFrame from the 'joined' Ray Dataset
# Note: This will convert the Ray Dataset to a Pandas DataFrame, which may not
# be suitable for very large datasets due to memory constraints.
preprocessed_df = tokenizer.transform(joined).to_pandas()

663391b4-005f-4ea9-a779-5bfce71f794c.source: This notebook demonstrates how to preprocess large datasets using Ray Data in a distributed and scalable way. It covers loading a public dataset (IMDB reviews), converting it to a Ray Dataset, filtering and joining data, applying tokenization, and converting the results to a Pandas DataFrame for further analysis. The workflow highlights how Ray Data enables efficient data processing for machine learning pipelines, even with datasets that are too large for a single machine.

cell_titles.9e6713c8-5ec5-4584-866f-c599ecc5090c-bef: Load IMDB Dataset from Hugging Face
cell_titles.922d6264-79f4-4b36-903b-fe10d6b53002-bef: IMDB Dataset Features and Row Count
cell_titles.2849aad6-d401-44e5-a841-0dd553b6473e-bef: Example IMDB Text and Labels Output
cell_titles.836acc09-8526-4e92-bdc4-aadbca82dd74-bef: Perform an Inner Join on ID
cell_titles.663391b4-005f-4ea9-a779-5bfce71f794c-bef: Summary of Ray Data Preprocessing Workflow

scene_notes.613d75fafb897394: Introduces the notebook topic and sets context for using Ray Data for scalable preprocessing. Learners understand the environment options (local vs. cloud) and the overall focus of the material.
scene_notes.9ed48264-2b2b-4894-9fed-11e742a0d154-bef: Provides a roadmap of the steps and examples covered in the notebook. This helps learners anticipate core operations like loading, transforming, and exporting data with Ray Data.
scene_notes.3792f83a-1de7-4b6d-b059-318aab4f2577-bef: Signals the dependencies needed before running the workflow. Learners see which libraries support distributed data processing (Ray), dataset access (Hugging Face), and tabular inspection (Pandas).
scene_notes.8f68cb99-c515-46a6-a473-7141c7bbf791-bef: Imports the core packages used throughout the notebook. Learners connect each import to its role: Ray for distributed datasets, `load_dataset` for sourcing data, and Pandas for local analysis.
scene_notes.eef969cf-97d7-4f6d-b407-26c1ef607d44-bef: Introduces the first hands-on workflow step: starting Ray and bringing in a real dataset. Learners understand how Ray Data fits into an end-to-end pipeline beginning with data ingestion.
scene_notes.fcb0937e-1d3e-482b-bed7-beaa9976609a-bef: Starts a Ray runtime so subsequent Ray Data operations can execute. Learners see the required initialization step for running distributed transformations.
scene_notes.9e6713c8-5ec5-4584-866f-c599ecc5090c-bef: Loads the IMDB dataset from Hugging Face as the raw input for preprocessing. Learners practice dataset acquisition and understand the concept of selecting a split (e.g., train).
scene_notes.4d388c71-8ca0-428a-9b5f-4f2be3d162ed-bef: Prints the dataset object to inspect its structure before transformation. Learners learn to verify features/columns and dataset size as a basic data validation step.
scene_notes.922d6264-79f4-4b36-903b-fe10d6b53002-bef: Shows the dataset schema (features) and number of rows. Learners interpret this output to confirm the dataset loaded correctly and understand what fields are available.
scene_notes.0f041831-08ba-410d-9966-06027ccc8bea-bef: Displays a small sample of records to ground later preprocessing steps. Learners practice quick qualitative inspection of text data and labels.
scene_notes.2849aad6-d401-44e5-a841-0dd553b6473e-bef: Provides the concrete sample output from the dataset preview. Learners see the raw text format and how labels are represented, informing later filtering and tokenization.
scene_notes.ba529922-e9b6-4061-9cdd-aa4e336cf59a-bef: Computes a simple label statistic to understand class balance. Learners practice basic exploratory checks that can influence preprocessing and modeling decisions.
scene_notes.ab7dc39c81c8b803: Demonstrates converting raw items into a Ray Dataset and adding unique IDs for downstream operations. Learners understand why stable keys matter for joins and distributed processing.
scene_notes.d9ccbf30e5b0f863: Creates a second dataset to simulate auxiliary metadata for enrichment. Learners learn how multi-table workflows are set up before performing joins in Ray Data.
scene_notes.00d8a1e4-a54e-4957-af8e-0ffb4af83791-bef: Introduces filtering as a core transformation for selecting relevant records. Learners understand how predicate-based filtering reduces dataset size and focuses analysis (e.g., positive reviews).
scene_notes.a2eda4be-3cf7-4da6-94b8-69f9ff6ee7c1-bef: Applies a filter operation using Ray‚Äôs expression API for performance and clarity. Learners see how to implement efficient distributed filtering and optionally tune execution (e.g., concurrency).
scene_notes.a7b13b3d-9694-4ad9-8e2a-8824de6fbdb2-bef: Prints the filtered dataset object to confirm the transformation succeeded. Learners practice validating intermediate pipeline outputs before chaining more operations.
scene_notes.7ef76d1e-e13e-4671-b53a-96d757df4d7d-bef: Introduces joining as a way to enrich records with additional columns from another dataset. Learners understand how relational operations apply in distributed Ray Datasets.
scene_notes.836acc09-8526-4e92-bdc4-aadbca82dd74-bef: Executes an inner join on the shared `id` key to combine reviews and metadata. Learners learn join types, key specification, and partitioning considerations for scalable joins.
scene_notes.0ec9908b-4591-4412-8bf8-74c6a79bc42e-bef: Samples a few joined rows to verify correctness and inspect the enriched schema. Learners see how to use `take()` for quick checks without materializing the full dataset.
scene_notes.847ca563-d299-44fe-ae40-ac43d357b31d-bef: Shows an example of the joined record output after the inner join. Learners confirm that fields from both datasets are present and aligned by the join key.
scene_notes.343cf4666b21d5d2: Defines and applies a tokenizer-style preprocessing function over text data. Learners understand how to implement custom text transformations (e.g., punctuation handling and token generation) in a Ray pipeline.
scene_notes.80634a0c-2833-47da-8986-e40be1aa6e66-bef: Explains exporting a processed Ray Dataset to Pandas for local inspection or downstream tooling. Learners learn when and why to convert from distributed to in-memory formats.
scene_notes.9c0ab43a-b01a-4a04-8802-0439a6bbded8-bef: Performs the conversion to a Pandas DataFrame from the (tokenized) Ray Dataset. Learners see the trade-off of materialization and how to obtain a familiar tabular object for analysis.
scene_notes.4d32cb0c-8a03-45eb-87c0-2435acbc702d-bef: Displays the first rows of the preprocessed DataFrame to validate the transformation results. Learners practice checking that tokenization and joins produced the expected columns and values.
scene_notes.4cbad799-46e7-45d8-8b71-a2fd8932c0e2-bef: Marks the cleanup step to end the Ray session responsibly. Learners understand good resource hygiene, especially important in shared or cloud environments.
scene_notes.f4802c51-ea5f-4e19-b81d-2f652e223065-bef: Shuts down Ray to release resources and avoid lingering processes. Learners see the explicit command used to terminate the Ray runtime at the end of a workflow.
scene_notes.d12aad48-2446-49a5-b8a4-d03e33dd24f7-bef: Signals a concluding section to reinforce what was accomplished. Learners are prompted to consolidate understanding of the pipeline steps and key Ray Data concepts.
scene_notes.663391b4-005f-4ea9-a779-5bfce71f794c-bef: Summarizes the end-to-end preprocessing workflow using Ray Data. Learners review the main operations‚Äîconversion, filtering, joining, tokenization, and export‚Äîand how they fit together.

scenes.name: scene_0
scenes.note: Introduces the notebook topic and sets context for using Ray Data for scalable preprocessing. Learners understand the environment options (local vs. cloud) and the overall focus of the material.

scenes.name: scene_1
scenes.note: Provides a roadmap of the steps and examples covered in the notebook. This helps learners anticipate core operations like loading, transforming, and exporting data with Ray Data.

scenes.name: scene_2
scenes.note: Signals the dependencies needed before running the workflow. Learners see which libraries support distributed data processing (Ray), dataset access (Hugging Face), and tabular inspection (Pandas).

scenes.name: scene_3
scenes.title: Import Ray, Datasets, and Pandas
scenes.note: Imports the core packages used throughout the notebook. Learners connect each import to its role: Ray for distributed datasets, `load_dataset` for sourcing data, and Pandas for local analysis.

scenes.name: scene_4
scenes.note: Introduces the first hands-on workflow step: starting Ray and bringing in a real dataset. Learners understand how Ray Data fits into an end-to-end pipeline beginning with data ingestion.

scenes.name: scene_5
scenes.title: Start a Local Ray Runtime
scenes.note: Starts a Ray runtime so subsequent Ray Data operations can execute. Learners see the required initialization step for running distributed transformations.

scenes.name: scene_6
scenes.title: Load IMDB Dataset from Hugging Face
scenes.note: Loads the IMDB dataset from Hugging Face as the raw input for preprocessing. Learners practice dataset acquisition and understand the concept of selecting a split (e.g., train).

scenes.name: scene_7
scenes.title: Inspect Dataset Schema and Size
scenes.note: Prints the dataset object to inspect its structure before transformation. Learners learn to verify features/columns and dataset size as a basic data validation step.

scenes.name: scene_8
scenes.title: IMDB Dataset Features and Row Count
scenes.note: Shows the dataset schema (features) and number of rows. Learners interpret this output to confirm the dataset loaded correctly and understand what fields are available.

scenes.name: scene_9
scenes.title: Preview Sample Rows from IMDB
scenes.note: Displays a small sample of records to ground later preprocessing steps. Learners practice quick qualitative inspection of text data and labels.

scenes.name: scene_10
scenes.title: Example IMDB Text and Labels Output
scenes.note: Provides the concrete sample output from the dataset preview. Learners see the raw text format and how labels are represented, informing later filtering and tokenization.

scenes.name: scene_11
scenes.title: Count Positive Labels in Dataset
scenes.note: Computes a simple label statistic to understand class balance. Learners practice basic exploratory checks that can influence preprocessing and modeling decisions.

scenes.name: scene_12
scenes.note: Demonstrates converting raw items into a Ray Dataset and adding unique IDs for downstream operations. Learners understand why stable keys matter for joins and distributed processing.

scenes.name: scene_13
scenes.note: Creates a second dataset to simulate auxiliary metadata for enrichment. Learners learn how multi-table workflows are set up before performing joins in Ray Data.

scenes.name: scene_14
scenes.note: Introduces filtering as a core transformation for selecting relevant records. Learners understand how predicate-based filtering reduces dataset size and focuses analysis (e.g., positive reviews).

scenes.name: scene_15
scenes.title: Filter for Positive Reviews Efficiently
scenes.note: Applies a filter operation using Ray‚Äôs expression API for performance and clarity. Learners see how to implement efficient distributed filtering and optionally tune execution (e.g., concurrency).

scenes.name: scene_16
scenes.title: Display the Filtered Ray Dataset
scenes.note: Prints the filtered dataset object to confirm the transformation succeeded. Learners practice validating intermediate pipeline outputs before chaining more operations.

scenes.name: scene_17
scenes.note: Introduces joining as a way to enrich records with additional columns from another dataset. Learners understand how relational operations apply in distributed Ray Datasets.

scenes.name: scene_18
scenes.title: Perform an Inner Join on ID
scenes.note: Executes an inner join on the shared `id` key to combine reviews and metadata. Learners learn join types, key specification, and partitioning considerations for scalable joins.

scenes.name: scene_19
scenes.title: Sample Joined Rows for Verification
scenes.note: Samples a few joined rows to verify correctness and inspect the enriched schema. Learners see how to use `take()` for quick checks without materializing the full dataset.

scenes.name: scene_20
scenes.title: Joined Record Example Output
scenes.note: Shows an example of the joined record output after the inner join. Learners confirm that fields from both datasets are present and aligned by the join key.

scenes.name: scene_21
scenes.note: Defines and applies a tokenizer-style preprocessing function over text data. Learners understand how to implement custom text transformations (e.g., punctuation handling and token generation) in a Ray pipeline.

scenes.name: scene_22
scenes.note: Explains exporting a processed Ray Dataset to Pandas for local inspection or downstream tooling. Learners learn when and why to convert from distributed to in-memory formats.

scenes.name: scene_23
scenes.title: Materialize Tokenized Data as DataFrame
scenes.note: Performs the conversion to a Pandas DataFrame from the (tokenized) Ray Dataset. Learners see the trade-off of materialization and how to obtain a familiar tabular object for analysis.

scenes.name: scene_24
scenes.title: Preview the Preprocessed DataFrame
scenes.note: Displays the first rows of the preprocessed DataFrame to validate the transformation results. Learners practice checking that tokenization and joins produced the expected columns and values.

scenes.name: scene_25
scenes.note: Marks the cleanup step to end the Ray session responsibly. Learners understand good resource hygiene, especially important in shared or cloud environments.

scenes.name: scene_26
scenes.title: Stop the Ray Runtime
scenes.note: Shuts down Ray to release resources and avoid lingering processes. Learners see the explicit command used to terminate the Ray runtime at the end of a workflow.

scenes.name: scene_27
scenes.note: Signals a concluding section to reinforce what was accomplished. Learners are prompted to consolidate understanding of the pipeline steps and key Ray Data concepts.

scenes.name: scene_28
scenes.title: Summary of Ray Data Preprocessing Workflow
scenes.note: Summarizes the end-to-end preprocessing workflow using Ray Data. Learners review the main operations‚Äîconversion, filtering, joining, tokenization, and export‚Äîand how they fit together.
